participants.participant: Patrick G. Flynn, Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Good morning. This is Kent, welcoming you to ING's First Quarter 2010 Conference Call.

Before handing this conference over to Jan Hommen, Chief Executive Officer of ING Group; Patrick Flynn, Chief Financial Officer; and Koos Timmermans, Chief Risk Officer, let me first say that any forward-looking statements in today's comments are subject to a number of current views, assumptions and variables including interest rates, foreign exchange rates, inflation rates, movements in securities markets including equity markets and underlying economic conditions and changes. These are set out in greater detail in our public filings, which we could urge you to read.
The realization of forward-looking statements could be materially altered by unexpected movements in any or all of these and other variables. Good morning Jan, Patrick and Koos. Jan, over to you.

Thank you very much. Welcome everyone on the telephone and also on the webcast. I am happy to report that we made a good start of the year. Of course markets started to stabilize or improve a little bit in first quarter and impairments and negative market impacts have diminished significantly from previous quarters.

However, our first quarter results also show the strengths of our franchises and we are seeing early progress on the performance improvement programs that we have set out for the insurance company as well as for the bank.

Volumes are up in banking, loan loss provisions are trending down and insurance also have gained momentum in this first quarter. Margins are stable quarter-on-quarter and efficiency has continued to improve on both sides of the business. So I think an encouraging start for the first quarter of the new year.

When I look at slide number two I would – well, you can read it yourself, but I will make a few comments. The underlying profit of just over 1 billion, that compares to a loss of 236 million in the year before. Bank underlying profit almost €1.3 billion, compared to 769 million a year ago. And importantly total income of the bank now is at levels that we have seen pre-crises.

Insurance had an underlying profit of 269 million, that compares to a loss of 954 a year ago and you can see here that non-operating items declined and operating profit for life and investments increased by 30%. So also here you see that – that the plans – the performance improvement plans are beginning to get hold.

Shareholders equity was up by 4.4 billion and shareholders equity is now €10.10 on a per share basis. And the return on equity on an annualized basis was up to 11.3 compared to 3.3% a year ago so, all-in-all a significant improvement on previous quarters and as I said earlier, a good start for the year 2010.

Slide number three. Here you see the improvements in underlying net results compared with previous quarters. And you clearly can see here as a result also that impairments and other market related impacts have diminished, but the volumes at the banks and the margins have continued to improve.

Expenses are under tight control and loan loss provisions have declined from both the first quarter as well as from the fourth quarter last year. Insurance has benefited from improved investment margins and cost containment which drove a 30% increase in operating profit from Life and IM. Importantly this improvement was very broad-based with almost all segments within the bank and the insurer showing higher result than a year ago.

On page four, slide four, you see on the top left the commercial performance for banking, on the right, the operating results for insurance both excluding market impacts. Both sides of the company are showing improving terms and real operating performance. And I can strength that again to say that this is reflecting the strengths of our franchise in both of our businesses.

In the middle part you see the negative market impacts and risk costs for the bank, both showing an improving trend as the market have stabilized and/or improved in the first quarter. And finally the underlying result, you see more volatility from quarter-to-quarter but clear improving trends for both the bank and insurance company.

On page number five, you see expenses for the quarter. Again here on expenses the reported numbers show little increase, but – compared with Q4, but it's a bit distorted by the fact that we had accruals for certain benefit programs that we moved into the year 2010, so Q4 got a benefit and the subsequent quarters and Q1 in particular got a little bit of a negative impact on that.

On the bank side, operating expense also include impairments on real estate and the DSB provision which is shown in orange, last year in Q4. On a like-for-like basis, if we compared that operating expenses are down 1.8% for the bank and 1.9% for the insurance company, if we compare that with last year.

Slide number six, you see that we are making good progress compared to the ambition that we have set for 2010. This slide shows the bank – our targets are top line growth of 5% so we did very well this quarter. Our cost income ratio, we want to see that trending down to 50%, it was 57, but if we eliminate the impact of impairments and market volatility, that is down to 53%.

Risk costs have been trending down to 59% or 59 basis points. Our target is 40 to 45 and you see that return on equity has gone up to 14.9, there is an objective of somewhere between 13 and 15%. So all in all I would say, we are approaching our objectives and ambitions and the ambitions I don't think are really that aggressive as many of you have felt earlier.

Page number seven, you see the insurance company, management set out performance improvement plans and they were shown at the Investor Day last month. It's still early days, but we are seeing really encouraging improvements in Q1. Investment margin in life and investment management was up by 10.4% driven by growth in the general account and also asset prices were higher.

Spreads increased slightly from Q4 to 84 basis points, but are still significantly lower than in Q1 last year. And that is of course reflecting the de-risking that we have taken during the year 2009. Efficiency has improved. The ratio of administrative expense relative to operating income declined to 43.5%, of course still higher than the 35% objective, but we're moving in the right direction here.

Sales of life insurance was up by 14% and that – and then we measure that we exclude the closed books in the U.S. as well as in Japan. Return on equity, whilst the low, improved to 3% and there is clearly that we need to do some work here, but I'm very encouraged by the fact that we have the improvements in Q1.

Slide number eight, you see shareholders equity up by 4.4 billion. It was up because of revaluations partly by foreign exchange and of course by the net profit that we booked. And equity now is almost double what it was a year ago.

Page nine, the capital ratios, all are better. Debt/equity is at 11.8%, core Tier 1 at 8.4, Tier 1 at 10.9, the FiCo ratio is at 162 and the insurance solvency at 261, all in all I would say, again here a good improvement.

Next slide, return on equity, that's up to 11.3% and a share – earnings per share at 0.35. You see the trend line and I think I'm very encouraged by the trend line here. Now let's summarize, a good first quarter results. We are making good progress on our priorities for 2010. Performance is improving both for the bank and the insurance company and we are approaching and being on our way to our long-term objectives that we have set for 2013. This year will be very important that we maintain our vigilance because markets still are volatile and yes, we have seen an improvement in the economy but it's quite fragile as you could see in the last couple of weeks with the concerns we have had about sovereign risk.

The bank and the insurance company are separating, as you know, and we are well on track to accomplish that by the end of the year. We have really taken inventory of all the issues. We are now in the design phase and we think we will be done by the end of this year.
And let me now hand over to Patrick, who will go more into the numbers. Patrick?

Good morning. Thank you, Jan. ING has had a strong first quarter. The total net result is a profit of 1.3 billion which compares to a loss of 793 in the same quarter of last year, a turnaround of 2 billion.
Underlying net result of 1 billion, which is before the profit and disposal of our private banking in Asia and Switzerland, compares to a 236 million loss in the same quarter of last year.
Underlying result before tax at both bank and insurance is up with the bank recording a profit of just under 1.3 billion, and insurance of 269 million.

Moving forward to the bank on slide 15, the underlying result before tax of – just under 1.3 billion, 1,278 million, is the highest we've seen in the previous five quarters, 66% higher than the first quarter of 2009. That was achieved on the back of underlying income up 11% and staff expenses when you exclude impairments, actually down 2%. In addition, loan loss provisions of 497 million are the lowest we've seen in the past five quarters and declined across all business lines.
Moving forward to underlying income, slide 16, as I said earlier, these levels are high, back to pre-crisis levels driven by lower impairments, strong margins and some volume growth.

Margins, slide 17, a key driver of performance, remain high at 142 basis points and indeed we've seen an increase in the margin at ING Direct to 118 we were at 98. However we do expect interest margins to decline over time to the long-term average we quoted at 120 basis points.

Volume growth in the Bank, slide 18, as compared to the previous quarter in retail we've seen some growth in mortgages and retail deposits. But on the commercial side the demand is more muted, just limited growth there.

Costs, slide 19, excluding impairments which have reduced, operating expenses declined 1.8% in line with our Back to Basics program. On the right hand side you can see the cost/income ratio on a headline basis which includes impairment is highly volatile. The red line below which excludes impairments which is closer to the managed number, is more stable and is at 53.5% which, as Jan said, compares well with our longer term target of 50%. Clearly we have still some work to do to achieve that. That is a target for 2013.

Retail banking on slide 20, Retail Banking underlying pre-tax profits have tripled to 867 million which is on the back of a good margins, reduction in cost, risk cost down 16.5%, cost/income ratio is improved to 56.2 from 71.6.
In addition as you can see on the right hand side, the mix of profit is more evenly balanced with a better balance between ING Direct, the Netherlands and Belgium.

Moving forward to slide 21, on the segmental results, you see that all our segments are in profit and all are reporting higher results than the same quarter of last year. The commercial bank, slide 22, reported a profit excluding real estate of 683 million which is down 2.7% from the same quarter of last year which you will recall, the first quarter of 2009 was in the depth of the crisis when spreads were at their widest.

On the right hand side, you can see the composition of our commercial banking results and here the red box shows the relative contribution of financial markets. And what we are seeing is that, this is reducing, is down to 32% of the total compared to 53 and we are seeing a stronger contribution from other business lines and those would be structured finance and general lending.
As I said, this excludes real estate and Koos will give you some further insights on development of the real estate portfolios a little later on.

Moving forward to insurance, this is the basic slide, but as we said in the Investor Day, we will be using this margin report as the key to explain the performance of our insurance business. Two lines here highlighted in red, underlying performance, 269, which we mentioned at the beginning, compares to loss of 954 in the preceding quarter. Perhaps more importantly operating results, which is before the impact of these volatile items, at 415 million that's an improvement of 63% as compared to the same results last year, that was achieved by income up 10.5% to 1.7 billion and strong cost control with admin expenses showing a modest 2% growth.

One point to note here in response to the reserve inadequacy we highlighted in the fourth quarter, we are no longer righting up DAC balances when markets improve in respect of the closed block VA business. This has led to a strengthening of reserve of approximately 100 million. Pre-tax, the same impact in results. In other words, results would have been approximately 100 million higher had this change not have been effected. Again, Koos will give you further insights into that element later on.

So how did the income levels increase in insurance? If we turn to slide 25, investment margin is up 10.4% to 329 million, this increase was achieved in the back of an increase in spreads and the growth in the – in volumes in the general account. The spread increase was partly attributable to investing cash assets in fixed income securities, achieving higher yield particularly in the Benelux. As Jan has mentioned the decline in spreads you can see on the graph on the right, is attributed to de-risking, particularly in the U.S.

Fees and premium based revenues in aggregate up 11% to 1.2 billion, show two components here. The top line loading on premiums is up 670 million in line with growth in sales on premiums. Fees on assets under management are up 22% even though the cost of guarantees increased so much due to lower interest rates.

Moving forward to slide 27, on admin expenses, if we exclude the impact of the accrual adjustment in respect of the deferral of variable comp awarded in fourth quarter -- our change in the fourth quarter, our expenses are actually down by 9% quarter-on-quarter.

And on the right-hand side you can see, as Jan said, that the key metric we flagged on the Investor Day we are seeking achieve admin expenses to operate income ratio of 35% by 2013 and at 43.4, this is trending in the right direction.

Segmental results on slide 28 with the exception of the U.S. all the segments are showing profits higher than the first quarter of 2009. I mentioned on the first page where I talked about the margin results. This slide 29 that we would be – excludes the impact of non-operating items, so it's worth spending a minute just explaining what they are.

In the first quarter on impairments we have taken a charge of an aggregate 200 million. This is primarily due to a 75 million realized loss on selling CMBS as we sought to reduce our exposure and 108 million impairment of subprime RMBS and CMBS.

The other market impact, it's reduced from 829 million to zero. This is where we record the impact of DAC unlocking, Japan SPVA hedging results and the NN separate account. These effects, while not individually zero, did net to zero in the first quarter and across all three lines are lower than previously.

Moving forward to sales on slide 30, sales increased 15.2%, if you exclude the closed blocks in the U.S. and Japan, which is attributable to presales in the Benelux, Asia and LatAm. In Asia we did benefit from the seasonally high COLI sales as the corporate tax year end approached.

So in summary, before I just hand over to Koos, ING has had a strong first quarter with an underlying net profit of 1 billion. Most of our ratios have moved in the right direction but we do remain vigilant, particularly in light of the recent market volatility.
And now I will hand you over to Koos who will take you through the risk section.

Okay, good morning. I would like to take you to first slide 32 if we take a step back and look at the whole picture then what you've seen is over the last year we have shortened our balance sheet significantly without sacrificing P&L or margins. We have basically doubled our equity and that is what you see back in an improvement of the leverage ratio. But what we have also done is apart from the core Tier-1 ratio, we have sort of yet made our balance sheet more shock absorbing also by reclassifications on the accounting side so that we are less susceptible to changes in impairments and everything else.

Also underlying what you see is that the loan book its start to stabilize, so lower risk costs. We actually see the first positive development of the RWAs I think over the last year we kept it in check but what you see now is actually a small improvement. At the same time what you see is that our ABS revaluation reserve that starts to become smaller and smaller in the negative territory.

Nevertheless does it mean like we are ready on the risk side? The answer is no, I mean we have to stay vigilant on the various aspects and we still do some measures of more precision surgery which is at the moment happening for instance in the real estate development part, which is happening in the CMBSs and the reserve adequacy.

So with asset values in the news, let's first go to the sovereign debt portfolio of ING. And overall, what you see on page 33 is that we have a government bond portfolio of 91 billion. That government bond portfolio it has a revaluation reserve which is positive on the 31st of March. And after all the movements with Greece and all the other countries, you still see that it's positive because inherently there is a hedge in there, because you have the boons and you have the other currencies where you have a positive gain at a time when it deteriorates in Greece. And if it reverses then you see it differently, but overall the price movements on the whole portfolio were not that significant for us.

But let's now move to the bank and we see the bank on page 35, what you see there is first the RWAs. It's interesting to note following, the RWA stayed stable. Now what you see there is actually on the loan book although the PDs in technical terms, the probabilities of default are still slightly higher, we have seen loss given default going down and you have some loans which come out of restructuring which also get a better rating, therefore our rating migration contributed this time.

We still see small upward adjustment on the prime, but net-net, the loan book was positive in terms of RWA production, you see 7 billion on foreign exchange there, and there you can just ignore it, because we hold some capital in dollars as well, so the foreign exchange move is basically irrelevant.

So let's move to the loan book to the NPLs. What you see on the loan book is actually the following. Total NPLs 2.1, so more or less stable. We see actually a positive development in mortgages U.S. because there it's stabilized. At the same time we've seen some increases in the leasing and in the real estate finance part and that is more particular in the areas of Spain and in the Netherlands. Overall we have a lot lower risk cost, because we've seen that in U.S. mortgages, we've seen that in structured finance, but we also see that in the Benelux in the mid-corp area, so those were the big contributors to a fall in our total risk costs.

Also what we have seen is if we look at the watch list where we already saw that our corporate side watch list was already declining a little bit. We see that right now also on the mid-corp and the other segments. So it's not a spectacular drop, but overall the watch list, so that is the room before you enter the doctor – the patients room, that is basically getting slightly smaller.

What we see there as well is if we draw conclusions from this that based on the current state of the economy and assuming no big relapse due to governments or other things, then you could say that our risk cost guidance for the next three quarters is more somewhere between what we had this quarter and the last – and the second half of last year whereas the previous time I told it's more second half of last year is the guidance. But we see it now more somewhere in between.

If we look at risk cost over time and then we are on page 37, what you see is actually there that gradual and modest trend downwards, but we also – I have to tell you one other small technical thing. Long-term the average for us is 40, 45 basis points but what I have given here is it's over RWAs instead of CRWAs. And the reason that we do it is we want to align it with the other ones. Does it mean a change, does it mean higher guidance, the answer is no. In essence the following is the case.

The denominator, the amount there, it stays the same. And the reason that it stays the same is that our RWAs to ORM and trading they have now been included, but at the same time the CRWAs per unit of loan produced are basically forecasted to be lower. So net-net denominator stays the same and therefore the amount of risk cost projected stays the same. This all ignores of course all the Basel III and all the other measures coming because that is still unknown. So overall that guidance stays the same.

So let's now turn from loans to securities. And I am on page 38. On page 38 what you see is the ABS portfolio and you see a decline in the revaluation reserve and again that is still something ongoing because if you look at Alt-A and if you look at it in April prices already move from 61 to 64.
So market prices of Alt-A are improving, nevertheless, what you still see is delinquencies and that is what you see on the top right hand side of the portfolio, they were still increasing.

Revaluation reserve on the Alt-A portfolio in total end of first quarter was minus 26 million which comprises of some bonds which have a positive revaluation reserve and that's for 96 million and some for 122 million have a negative revalue reserve. What we had in this quarter is impairments 52 million over an expected credit loss of 20 million. So overall those amounts are getting smaller.

Let's now turn to real estate development. On the real estate development side -- let's first before we talk about real estate development – let's first before we talk about real estate development if we talk about and the investment portfolios. In general what you see there is you see that there is a stabilization in terms of revaluations. And why is that happening? In general the cap rates they are stabilizing at around 7% and at the same time the occupancies are still edging a little bit lower but not too much, I think that went down by 1%. So overall you discount a little bit lower cash flows with the same cap rate but that leads to far less revaluations.

But turning now RED [Real Estate Development], on the RED side what you see is over the last year we had 3 [inaudible] portfolio but what we took already last year is 600 million of impairments and we sold 300 million. This quarter we had a 151 million impairments the expectation is that the amounts will gradually start to edge off in this year because we are still looking at all these projects with the lot of scrutiny.

If we then move to the insurance company and then we are on page 31, on the insurance company you see – 41, sorry. What you on the see on the insurance company is in general, the general account it moved up by 10 billion contributed largely to foreign exchange as well as revaluations. We still did some de-risking and that is with CMBSs and I'll come back to that. And on the U.S. insurance side, the focus for investments at the moment is more on the corporate side. if you look at public equities, we hold some public equities in general a third of it is hedged, you benefit little bit in the hedge because you do that with stock 50 indexes including financials and our portfolio doesn't contain financials which have a bit of higher beta. So that's in a nutshell the developments on the general account.

Turning to CMBSs what you see in the U.S., you've seen price increases from 77 to 84 which meant that we saw that as an opportunity to sell some of the CMBS portfolio, remaining is basically 44% AAA, credit enhancement 21% and debt service capacity ratio constant at 1.6% nevertheless the price improvements will be used for some more active portfolio management at least we have the opportunity to do that. So on the CMBSs some changes happening overtime.

Then if we turn to the reserve adequacy on page 43, just the step back there on this part, we have a reserve adequacy and the reserve adequacy is a net number, its net of DAC. Now not writing the DAC up helps basically in this case to reserve adequacy. So what is happening there is a following, if we take it into a sensitivity, we normally assume 2.25% growth of the equity market per quarter.

If you have now a quarter that you have 15% equity growth, then typically what you see happening is that your reserve adequacy it will move up and it will move up by 0.6 billion and your DAC will stay unchanged. So that's basically profits will not be taken and it will be added to the reserve. So it strengthens. At the same time, if the market moves down 15% from the 2.25, you would see your DAC basically go down by 450 million and your reserve will move up, but DAC and reserves at the same time move up and down means then that your reserve adequacy doesn't change.

So overall positive markets will strengthen your reserve adequacy, negative markets will not do anything. That is basically the change which has been made and therefore you now have the sensitivities of the DAC as well. So those are in a nutshell the risk management things done. So working on the real estate development side, working on the real estate development side, working on the CMBS side, working on the VAs, but overall you are looking at a bit better situation in terms of balance sheet and the lot of things have been stabilized both in terms of balance sheet as well as in terms of the loan portfolio and then I hand back to you, Jan.

Thank you, Koos. Well, to summarize, I think it was a good quarter, good start of the year, with encouraging numbers. Performance improved both at the banks as well as at the insurance company. And we're approaching our longer term ambitions not everywhere yet but I think we are making good progress towards those ambitions.

We will continue to work hard this – the rest of this year to make sure that we stay vigilant when markets are still quite volatile as we have seen recently. The attention is still on the further improving the operating results at the bank and at the insurance company and to be ready by the end of this year with the full separation of bank and insurance organization.
And with that, I think we are happy to take your questions.
. The first question comes from Duncan Russell [JPMorgan]. Please go ahead.

Great. Good morning. I have two questions, please. First question is I was just wondering if you could update us on the European Commission and the Dutch government with respect to the Dutch government capital and the restructuring program etcetera, particularly in the light of the recent developments in Europe and the extent of the bailout we are seeing now across the whole of Europe. Does that change – or are you aware of that changing either the view of the EC or the Dutch government with respect to your particular capital injection awhile back? That's the first question.
The second question is just on the U.S. life sales, could you just provide a bit of color please on the sales in the retirement business in the U.S.? Thank you.

Okay, Duncan, good morning. The first question on the European Commission, we have seen that the European Commission has filed an answer with the European Court on the appeal that we have made against – and remember we have appealed the amount of state support as calculated. We have appealed some of the price regulations we are subjected to and the proportionality of the total package. We are getting ready to make a reply to that reply that we have to file I think some time in the next – in June. And then we will wait what the European Court will do with respect to probably getting oral testimony from parties sometime later this year or sometime next year. That's all we know at this moment.

The European Court has decided not to give us an accelerated procedure. But we are now in an – let's say priority procedure with the full three topics still on the docket. More than that, I can not tell you, because we don't really know more than that.

With respect to, does this change the position the recent situation and the need for restructuring maybe, we don't know. We have not had any – this is all quite fresh. We have not had any further discussions on the topic. So I can not give you an answer there.
Koos – Tom, would you like to deal with the U.S. Life?

Yeah, I think, Duncan, you asked a question on the retirement service sales in the first quarter. The full service plans, so that's where we're providing asset management and record keeping, were up just under 5%, so some improvement there. On the large end is more lumpy and there the quarter was flat to where we've been. So no big sales but good sales in full service plans.
Are you doing as well as the market, Tom, or better, worse?

Yeah, if you look at the two segments that we really focus on which would be K212 and 401(k) full service plans. We have maintained market share in the fourth quarter and continue in the first quarter. The full numbers aren't out, but we think we are still where we were in terms of market share in our respective ranking of one in K212 and two in the corporate plans.
Okay, thank you.
Thank you. The next question comes from Johnny Vo [Goldman Sachs]. Please go ahead.
Thanks. Obviously, you're building up capital nicely in the bank with a core tier-1 of 8.4%. Can you talk about that excess relative to your target and what you are likely to do with that capital?

Number two is can you just generically talk about the fungibility of capital in the insurance business. Clearly you have excess in the bank. What about in the insurance and the movement of that capital in insurance and the movement of that capital insurance business?

And just finally, in terms of the insurance business as well, just on your closed books, can you talk about any deviation of policyholder behavior relative to your assumptions in those books, please? Thanks.

First question the capital, yes we have – I think we are nicely building up capital in the bank. We are at 8.4, our target is about 7.5 which means that we are building excess capital. We probably will at some point move that to the holding company to have more flexibility with that capital and be in a position to either pay down debt or to use that for other purposes. As you know, we still have to repay the Dutch government and also therefore we need to build up some additional capital.
Fungibility, capital and the insurance company Matt or Tom.

Yeah, let me take that one, Johnny. So if you look at the capital ratios in insurance in the U.S., the RBC ratio was up in the first quarter. I think we ended the quarter at about 390 versus about 360 in the fourth quarter last year and the overall solvency ratio on an EU Solvency 1 basis was 261.
In terms of the closed book, no changes in terms of lapse or other assumptions.
Okay. Brilliant. Thanks.
Thank you. The next question comes from Spencer Horgan [Deutsche Bank], please go ahead.

Yeah. Thank you very much. Firstly, could I just kind of follow-up on that last question because I guess, what I thought he was getting at is there is essentially sort of 3 billion odd of capital that you could at least upstream to the holding company from the bank, if you were to take the Tier 1 dumps target, but it is not sort of quite clear what capital level you actually think this is appropriate on the insurance side. I mean, is 261% about right do you think? Maybe you could answer that by reference to the economic capital position of the insurance business at the end of the quarter.

And then the second thing was on the net interest margin, which is you've said before you expect to normalize to about 120 basis points over time. Could you give us a sort of update on what you think the timeframe for that potential normalization is? And in particular is sort of margin on your business, if I can call that, already being written on a sort of 120 basis point margin? Thanks very much.

Yeah, I think to answer in terms of the insurance capital ratios, we are clearly focused on trying to keep our capital ratios in line with where the competitors are, so you can see as I talked about in the U.S. the RBC ratio went up and overall went up. I think you're seeing that with competitors in general, just building some of the capital positions, given where we are in the cycle. So our main issue there is to have capital ratios at AA, AA minus standards, and looking to be in line with our competitors that are also increasing.
Okay. On the net interest margin, Patrick would you like to take that one?

Yes, Spencer. If you – as you look at the graph you can see that the interest margin in aggregate is reaching a peak. I think that we've talked about re-pricing and how that's been favorable but margins are tightening as competition comes back. So we think it's broadly as high as it's likely to go, it was 40 – last quarter 141, and over time it will trend down to the 120. We can't give you a precise quarter-by-quarter analysis on that.

By the way -- maybe by the time that we see a decline, we also see that loan demand for this moment is quite weak. So maybe we can get an offset maybe the margin will get a little bit lower but that might be offset by more demand for loans so that I think is going to play well when the market continues to recover.
Okay. Thanks.
Thank you. The next question comes from Jan Willem Weidema. Please go ahead.

Good morning, gentlemen. Jan Willem Weidema at Fortis Bank, Netherlands. Three questions from my end. Can you say something about development of risk costs and how you expect that to develop for the remainder of the year?

Basically the same for the Netherlands -- for the NPL, sorry, and especially for the Netherlands? Will you see an increase there and what do you expect there with regard to a lag there in unemployment rates and how that affects NPLs?
And thirdly how and where are you expecting to scale down your real estate development pipeline?

Jan Willem, if you look at risk cost, indeed first quarter was below 500 million. Last time I gave guidance which was more on average the second half of '09. I think going forward during the next quarters, we see it somewhere in between. So lower than the second half of '09 the average but maybe a little bit higher than what we have right now. So – and again being more refined than this is difficult because it can always be on the positive side be influenced by a release or on the negative side with one addition so, trending down again as compared to the guidance which I gave for last time.

If you look at the NPLs basically we see the NPLs at the moment we have seen it kind of stabilize and given the fact that the watch list is not growing. Normally, we should assume that NPLs don't necessarily overall increase. Now you could have certain segments where you at a quarter it goes up or down but then again that is more driven by incidence. If you look at the Netherlands NPLs, that is more driven by the mortgages and the mortgages are more linked to unemployment and at the moment you don't have the indicators that you should expect a large increase on that side. And again I mean very much related to the unemployment numbers what we see.

If you go to the development side, the scale down. I mean what we are doing is it's not exiting something like country-by-country. What we are looking at -- we are more looking at it project-by-project. And on some of these projects if we have – if we foresee that the further development will be difficult then the question becomes do you write down your accrued cost or do you sell something, do you sell a lien position or do you continue to develop.
